questions.text: A 35-year-old HIV positive​ patient presents with mucosal lesions in the mouth as shown in the image below. On microscopy, budding yeasts and pseudohyphae are seen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
An HIV patient with white patches over the tonsils and posterior pharynx showing budding yeasts and pseudohyphae on microscopy suggests a diagnosis of oral candidiasis.

Oral candidiasis or thrush is a patchy, pseudomembranous lesion that develops over the tongue, lips, gum or palate. It is composed of epithelial cells, yeasts, and pseudohyphae and can be scraped off. The causative agent is usually Candida albicans. It occurs in almost all individuals with AIDS. Other risk factors include hyperglycemia, cellular immunodeficiency, corticosteroids or antibiotics. It is treated with topical nystatin, oral ketoconazole or fluconazole.

Option B: Hairy leukoplakia is a wart-like growth on the tongue, caused by Epstein-Barr virus. It is commonly seen as a white lesion on the lateral side of the tongue.

Option C: Lichen planus is a pruritic disease characterized by papules commonly seen over the flexor surfaces and trunk. Oral and vulvovaginal lesions may also occur. Oral lesions appear as lacy, white, and raised lesions.

Option D: Diphtheria is characterized by the presence of a grey pseudomembrane covering the tonsils and pharynx. It is caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

questions.text: Zika virus is transmitted by:
questions.solution:
Zika virus is transmitted by the bite of infected Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus.

Zika virus is an RNA virus belonging to the Flaviviridae group. The symptoms of Zika virus disease include fever, maculopapular rash, conjunctivitis, muscle and joint pain, malaise and headache. These symptoms are mild and usually last for 2-7 days. It can be misdiagnosed as dengue or influenza. In severe cases, it can lead to complications like Guillain-Barré syndrome, neuropathy, and myelitis.

Zika virus infection during pregnancy may lead to microcephaly or congenital Zika syndrome. 

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes, and Mansonia
  • Flight range varies up to 11 km, except Aedes for which it is 100 meters
  • The life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi, and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen
  • The larval stage lasts for 5 to 7 days

questions.solution:

questions.text: Identify the class of immunoglobulin​ shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The above image shows a dimeric structure, characteristic of secretory IgA.

IgA immunoglobulin is the major antibody responsible for mucosal immunity. Its serum levels are usually low. It is predominantly present in the extravascular secretions. It is present in secretions such as milk, saliva, and tears, and in secretions of the respiratory, intestinal, and genital tracts.

When present in the serum, it exists as a monomer similar to IgG. However, when it is secreted, it exists as a dimer. The dimeric structure consists of two monomers, which are stabilized by two additional polypeptides:

  • J chain, which stabilizes the molecule.
  • Secretory component, which is incorporated into the IgA when transported through the epithelial cell.

Related Pearl: Properties of immunoglobulin classes

IgG:

  • Half-life- 23 days
  • Appears late, indicates chronic infection
  • It is the only maternal Ig to cross the placenta.
  • Has 4 subclasses.
  • Causes complement fixation, precipitation, and neutralization of toxins and virus.

IgM:

  • Half-life- 5 days
  • Has the highest molecular weight and is a pentamer.
  • Polysaccharides and lipids mainly stimulate IgM secretion.
  • Intravascular distribution.
  • Appears early, indicates recent infection.
  • Acts as surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • It causes agglutination, hemolysis, complement fixation and opsonization.

IgD:

  • Half-life- 2-8 days.
  • Acts as a surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • Serves as recognition receptors for antigens.

IgE:

  • Half-life- 1-5 days
  • Causes type I hypersensitivity.
  • It is the only heat labile antibody.
  • Levels are raised in helminthic infections.

IgA:

  • Half-life- 6 days
  • It is of 2 types- Serum IgA and Secretory IgA 
  • Secretory IgA (A dimer) results in mucosal immunity.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with a history of vomiting within 3 hours of consumption of food at a party. Which of the following organism is most likely to cause these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Vomiting 2 hours after the consumption of food is likely food poisoning by Staphylococcus aureus. 

Staphylococcus aureus can grow in carbohydrate and protein food sources, producing enterotoxins. There are 15 types, all of which are superantigens. They are preformed toxins that are relatively heat stable. They stimulate the vagus nerve,  vomiting centre of the brain and intestinal peristaltic activity. Type A enterotoxin is responsible for most cases of food poisoning. 

The common sources of infection are the foods that are not cooked after handling. These include sliced meats, puddings, pastries, and sandwiches. Ingestion of such contaminated food causes food poisoning within 30 minutes to 6 hours after consumption. Patients present with nausea, vomiting, stomach cramps, and diarrhoea.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms produces superantigen?
questions.solution:
Streptococcus pyogenes produces streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxin (SPE), which is a superantigen.

Superantigens are protein toxins that stimulate large numbers of T cells, irrespective of antigen specificity. They bind to the class II MHC molecule outside the peptide-binding groove and Vβ region of the TCR. Some examples of superantigens are staphylococcal enterotoxins, toxic shock syndrome toxin, and group A streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxin.

questions.text: A female patient who is from the north-eastern part of the country came to the hospital with complaints of progressive swelling of the upper limbs. She has a history of coronary artery disease for which she underwent percutaneous coronary intervention. On examination, the upper limbs are more swollen proximally than distally. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of filariasis. The next best step would be to test the night blood for worms since the filarial species is nocturnally periodic (between 10 pm and 4 am) in India.

questions.text: Which of the following helminthic infections, that is commonly transmitted by soil, is characterized by​ the egg in stool as shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the egg of Trichuris trichiura (whipworm).

The characteristic features of whipworm eggs are:

  • Barrel-shaped in the middle
  • Projecting colourless mucus plug at each pole
  • Contains an unsegmented ovum. 
  • Floast in the saturated salt solution.
  • It has a triple shell. The outermost layer is stained brown.

Humans acquire infection by swallowing embryonated eggs in contaminated food or water.  The eggs hatch in the small intestine, and the larvae produced pass into the cecum. The larvae become mature adults in 2-3 months. Adult females pass immature un-embryonated eggs in the stool. Thus, diagnosis of whipworm infection is done by microscopic identification of the eggs in a stool specimen. 

Most infections are asymptomatic. Moderate whipworm infection (20 adult worms or less), the worms are confined to the caecum and ascending colon. The symptoms include epigastric and lower abdominal pain, diarrhoea (rarely bloody), vomiting, flatulence and distention, weight loss, and increased blood and iron loss. In heavy infections of 200 adult worms or more - trichuriasis dysentery syndrome -, the worms are in the distal colon and rectum. The symptoms include bloody diarrhoea with profuse mucus, abdominal pain, tenesmus, weight loss leading to cachexia, severe anemia, and rectal prolapse. On examination, clubbing may be present. Blood investigations may show moderate eosinophilia.

Chronic infection leads to growth retardation and nutritional deficiencies. Around 0.005 ml of blood is lost per day per worm. In heavy infections, as much as 4 to 5 ml can be lost per day per worm. Treatment is mebendazole or albendazole.

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: The test kit shown in the image below works on the principle of:
questions.solution:
The above image shows a HbsAg card test kit which works on the principle of immunochromatography.

In immunochromatography, a nitrocellulose membrane is used to absorb the antigen from a specimen. The membrane is impregnated with anti-HBsAg antibody and colloidal gold dye. The specimen (serum) travels through the membrane by capillary action. If the serum contains HBaAg, a coloured reaction (in the form of a band) appears directly on the membrane at the test site. These assays are rapid and include a built-in internal control.

questions.text: A 22-year-old student presented with high-grade fever, and purpuric rash as shown in the image below. CSF sample showed gram-negative diplococci. Which of the following is the most likely aetiology?
questions.solution:
This patient has a high-grade fever and is a student, so he presumably spends a lot of time in crowded areas. The above image shows a purpuric rash. This patient's features are seen in meningococcemia caused by Neisseria meningitidis, which are gram-negative diplococci. 

The organism enters the body through the nasopharynx by attaching to the epithelial cells with the help of pili. From the nasopharynx, they enter the bloodstream producing bacteremia, and the symptoms may resemble upper respiratory tract infection.

Fulminant meningococcemia is the severe form, where the patient presents with high-grade fever and hemorrhagic rash. There is thrombosis of several small blood vessels in various organs with perivascular infiltration and petechial hemorrhages. Some patients with fulminant meningococcemia may also develop disseminated intravascular coagulation, and circulatory collapse, a condition known as Waterhouse–Friderichsen syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following is the predominant pathogen to infect renal transplant recipients one to four months following transplantation?
questions.solution:
The predominant pathogen to infect renal transplant recipients in the period around 1 to 4 months following the transplantation is cytomegalovirus (CMV).

CMV is the most common virus to affect recipients after organ transplantation (kidney, heart, lung etc). The maximal risk occurs between 1 and 4 months after transplantation (in the absence of prophylaxis). The most common CMV presentation in kidney transplant patients includes fever, leukopenia, hepatosplenomegaly, myalgia, and arthralgia. Antiviral prophylaxis with ganciclovir or valganciclovir is used in renal transplant recipients whenever indicated to prevent CMV disease. 

Given below are the most common opportunistic infections in renal transplant recipients:

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Japanese encephalitis?

choices.text: Vaccinating pigs is helpful in disease control

questions.solution:
Humans are the dead-end hosts for the Japanese encephalitis virus.

Japanese encephalitis is an endemic viral infection transmitted by mosquitoes. There is an increased risk in travelers to rural areas. JE has an inactivated vero culture-derived vaccine, given as 2 primary series to adults who are travelling to endemic areas. 

Other options: 

Option A: The disease is transmitted by Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnui (common in India) species.

Option B: Herons act as reservoir hosts and pigs as amplifier hosts.

Option D: The control measures include mosquito control, locating piggeries away from the human dwellings and vaccinating pigs.

questions.text: Which of the following helps in bacterial adhesion?
questions.solution:
Fimbriae help in bacterial adhesion.

Fimbriae, also called pili, are hair-like surface appendage that projects from the cell surface as straight filaments. They are primarily seen in Gram-negative bacteria. They are polymers of pilin. Fimbriae are classified based on the function as ordinary pili - for adhesion - and sex pili - involved in bacterial conjugation. The functions of pili are given below:

  • Bacterial conjugation through sex pili, which transfer of genetic material occurs.
  • Bacterial adhesion of symbiotic and pathogenic bacteria to host cells using adhesins.
  • Resistance to phagocytosis.
  • Antigenic pilin proteins are responsible for the immune response.
  • Twitching motility to bacteria.

questions.text: A 30-year-old HIV-positive patient presented with a chronic history of watery diarrhea. Histopathology of the ​duodenum is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The histopathology shows trophozoites of Giardia lamblia in the duodenal lumen (marked in arrows).

  • Giardia lamblia, also called Giardia duodenalis, is the causative agent of giardiasis. It is the only common pathogenic protozoan found in the duodenum and jejunum of humans.
  • Infection is acquired by the consumption of water or food contaminated with cysts and may also be transmitted by the faeco-oral route.
  • It is weakly pathogenic in humans. Secretory IgA and IL-6 are responsible for clearing the infection. Hence, giardiasis usually occurs in immunosuppressed, agammaglobulinemia, or malnourished individuals.
  • The symptoms include acute or chronic diarrhea, weight loss, malaise, abdominal cramps, distension, and weakness. The stools may be watery, greasy, bulky, or foul-smelling at various times during the course of the infection.
  • Histopathology of the duodenum reveals several heart-shaped or pear-shaped trophozoites with two equally sized nuclei. The small intestinal morphology is usually normal. However, in heavy infections, there may be villous blunting and intraepithelial infiltrates.

Did you know?

Giardia was discovered by Antonie van Leeuwenhoek when he found the organisms in his own watery diarrheal stools!

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for invasive pulmonary aspergillosis?
questions.solution:
Voriconazole is the drug of choice in the treatment of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis. 

Voriconazole can also be used against Candida species (including glabrata and krusei), Scedosporium and Fusarium. The other options - itraconazole, posaconazole, lyophylised Amphotericin B - can be used as alternatives for the treatment of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis if voriconazole is unavailable.

questions.text: Which of the following culture media is used to differentiate other E.coli species from E.coli O157: H7?
questions.solution:
E.coli O157: H7 can be differentiated from other E.coli species using sorbitol MacConkey agar. 

There are more than 150 serotypes of Shiga toxin-producing E.Coli (STEC). Of these, O157:H7 is the most common type. Unlike most other E.Coli serotypes, the STEC O157:H7 does not use sorbitol and produces clear colonies on the Sorbitol MacConkey agar.

O157: H7 strains also are negative for β-glucuronidase using the substrate 4-methylumbelliferyl-β-glucuronide (MUG) test. More than 90 per cent of other E.coli tests positive with this substrate.

questions.text: A 5 year old boy was suffering from low grade fever, inspiratory stridor and barking cough for past 5 days. His chest X-ray is given below. What is the cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Barking cough is a feature of laryngotracheobronchitis, which is caused by the parainfluenza virus. The X-ray finding is the 'Steeple sign' due to subglottic narrowing.

The age of presentation of laryngotracheobronchitis ranges from 6 months-6 years. The clinical features include barking cough, inspiratory stridor, hoarseness, low-grade fever.

Management:

  • Racemic epinephrine nebulization leads to the rapid improvement of upper airway obstruction. Epinephrine constricts pre-capillary arterioles in the upper airway mucosa and decreases capillary hydrostatic pressure, leading to fluid resorption and improvement in airway edema.
  • Dexamethasone-by the least invasive route (Oral>IV>IM ). It is indicated in all the grades of croup.
  • Oxygen should be administered to children who are hypoxemic (SpO2 <92 %)

Antibiotics are not indicated in laryngotracheobronchitis.
